work.name: Université de Genève
work.summary: I recruited, assessed and supervised MCI patients, and trained their caregivers for a clinical research trial on the possible behavioral benefits during and after a 3-month long transcranial stimulation procedure. The stimulations, targeting the left angular gyrus, were performed at home by the caregivers while our team supervised the sessions remotely.

work.name: Université de Genève
work.summary: While I decided to interrupt my PhD, I was offered to continue and finish my work related to ASR implementation and experimental data analysis. During that period, I worked closely with a small team of two undergraduate research assistants who assisted me in improving ASR quality.

work.name: Université de Genève
work.summary: I joined the EduGame Work Package of the NCCR Evolving Language. The project aimed at leveraging action video games' mechanics to foster reading acquisition in children. I was involved in the design and development of an automated, computerized cognitive and reading assessment battery that was to be used to assess the impact of a gamified attentional control training on executive functions and reading skills. I was also responsible for the implementation of automatic speech recognition solutions in the battery to improve the independence of the children during the verbal tests of the battery. Finally, I was responsible for the processing, analysis and interpretation of the assessment's results.

publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.
